content: The Act may be cited as the "Microcredit for Self-Sufficiency Act of 1998". Congress finds that over 1 billion people in the developing world live in severe poverty, with high child mortality rates and preventable deaths from malnutrition and disease. Women in poverty face greater workloads and fewer opportunities compared to men. Nearly 33,000 children die each day from malnutrition and disease in developing countries, with women in poverty facing larger workloads and fewer opportunities than men. Directly aiding the poorest, especially women, has a positive impact on family incomes, child nutrition, health, and education. Directly aiding the poorest women in the developing world has a positive effect on family incomes, child nutrition, health, and education. Women often lack stable employment and turn to self-employment to support their families, but struggle to access credit at reasonable rates to improve their livelihood. Many poor women in the developing world lack stable employment and social safety nets, leading them to turn to self-employment. However, they struggle to access credit at reasonable rates to expand their businesses, often resorting to high-interest loans. An international Microcredit Summit aimed to expand access to credit for self-employment and other financial services to 100 million of the world's poorest families by 2005. The Summit in Washington, D.C., aimed to expand access to credit for self-employment and financial services to 100 million of the world's poorest families, particularly women, by 2005. This initiative would benefit nearly half of the world's 1 billion absolute poor by providing loans at reasonable interest rates, enabling them to grow their incomes and businesses significantly. The goal is to expand access to microcredit for the world's absolute poor, allowing them to increase their incomes and businesses significantly. NGOs like the Grameen Bank have been successful in lending directly to the very poor. NGOs like the Grameen Bank, Accion International, and FINCA have successfully provided microcredit to the very poor, with repayment rates of 95% or higher. Microcredit institutions not only reduce poverty but also decrease dependency on foreign aid by using interest income to cover institutional costs. Microcredit institutions with high repayment rates reduce poverty and foreign aid dependency. Interest income covers institutional costs, ensuring long-term sustainability. Loans are recycled, leveraging foreign assistance resources for new benefits to participants. Sustainable microcredit institutions provide credit, training, and mobilize development. The development of sustainable microcredit institutions is crucial for poverty reduction and economic development. In 1994, AID launched a Microenterprise Initiative to expand funding for microenterprise programs. In 1994, AID launched a Microenterprise Initiative with a funding goal of $137,000,000 for fiscal year 1994. The initiative aimed to support programs providing credit to the poorest with loans under $300 by the end of fiscal year 1996. Total funding for microenterprise increased in fiscal year 1996. In fiscal year 1996, AID's microenterprise funding decreased to $111,000,000, with only 39 percent allocated to programs benefiting the poorest with loans under $300. The Act defines terms like "AID", "microcredit", "microenterprise", and "PVOs and other nongovernmental organizations" in relation to the 1994 Microenterprise Initiative of AID. The term "PVOs and other nongovernmental organizations" refers to private voluntary organizations, including cooperative organizations, and international, regional, or national nongovernmental organizations active in the region where the project is located and capable of developing microenterprise programs. Cooperative organizations and international, regional, or national nongovernmental organizations in the region where the project is located have the capacity to develop and implement microenterprise programs for the poor, especially women. SEC. 4. MICROENTERPRISE ASSISTANCE. The President, through the Administrator of AID, is authorized to establish programs for microenterprise assistance in developing countries. Programs will be carried out by US PVOs and other organizations, including credit unions and private financial intermediaries. Eligibility criteria will be established by the Administrator of AID. Activities under this section shall be primarily carried out by United States PVOs and indigenous nongovernmental organizations, including credit unions and private financial intermediaries. The Administrator of AID will establish eligibility criteria for determining which entities are eligible to carry out the purposes described in section 2(b), based on factors such as access to the local formal financial sector for credit recipients. Eligibility criteria for entities to carry out section 2(b) purposes include access to formal financial sector, serving the poorest, focusing on poor women, and self-reliance through realistic interest rates. Entities eligible to carry out section 2(b) purposes must work directly with poor women and aim to achieve financial self-reliance by charging realistic interest rates. Funding levels for fiscal year 1999 require a minimum of $160,000,000 to be used for assistance under this Act. Funding levels for fiscal year 1999 mandate at least $160,000,000 to be used for assistance under this Act, separate from funds allocated for microenterprise activities in the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. In fiscal year 1999, at least $160,000,000 must be used for assistance under this Act, with an additional $80,000,000 allocated for poverty lending. Support is also provided for pvos and other nongovernmental organizations. In fiscal year 1999, $80,000,000 must be used for poverty lending, and $35,000,000 for supporting PVOs and other NGOs. In fiscal year 1999, $35,000,000 must be provided through AID for support of United States PVOs and indigenous nongovernmental organizations, with an additional $10,000,000 allocated for the private voluntary organizations matching grant program. In fiscal year 1999, $10,000,000 is allocated for the private voluntary organizations matching grant program to support United States PVOs. The term "to support poverty lending" refers to funds lent to members of the poverty target population in low-income countries in amounts equivalent to $300 or less in 1997 United States dollars, and funds used for institutional development of an entity engaged in poverty lending. Funds in low-income countries for making loans of $300 or less in 1997 USD to poverty target population members or for institutional development of entities engaged in poverty lending. The term "poverty target population" refers to the poorest 50% of individuals living below the poverty line in a foreign country. This includes making small loans or participating in poverty lending programs. SEC. 5. PROGRAM PERFORMANCE CRITERIA. The Administrator of AID is required to strengthen mechanisms for microenterprise programs and develop systems for monitoring the impact of assistance provided under section 4. The Administrator of AID must develop mechanisms for microcredit targeting the poorest population and establish a monitoring system to measure project performance and recommend adjustments. The Administrator of AID must establish a monitoring system with performance goals and indicators to measure project success and recommend adjustments to enhance assistance for the very poor, especially women. The Administrator of AID must establish a monitoring system to track microenterprise credit and loans for the poverty target population, especially women, to enhance assistance for the very poor. The Administrator of AID must monitor microenterprise credit and loans for the poverty target population, report to Congress annually on the progress. The Administrator of AID shall monitor funding allocated to organizations providing loans under $300 to the poverty target population and report annually to Congress on progress towards expanding access to credit for the world's poorest families, especially women, by 2005. The Administrator of AID will report annually to Congress on the progress in implementing the institutional plan to achieve the Microcredit Summit goal of expanding access to credit for 100 million of the world's poorest families by 2005, with a focus on women. Additionally, a summary of the information collected will be included in AID's annual presentation to Congress.
